div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: EXPRESS SERVICE FROM NOVEMBER 1ST, UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE.

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. From Nov. 1st sleeping and dining cars on Egyptian State Railways are attached to ordinary trains from Cairo on Mon., Wed., and Sat. at 3 p.m. and from Luxor on Tues., Thurs. and Sun. at 5.30 p.m.- From 2nd Dec. Luxe trains with sleeping and dining. Cars will run on same days leaving Cairo and Luxor at 6.30 p.m. Early in January these trains will be run daily. Express between Shellal and Halfa carry mails and 1st class passaengers only, but 2nd class passengers may be accepted if accomadation is available. Express steamers do not stop at any stations on either up or down journeys between Shellal and Halfa. To insure accommodation official passengers must have warrants stamped "Accommodation Available" by Sudan Agent, Cairo, or Civil Secretary, Khartoum. A specially fitted barge with 1st and 2nd class accommodations for native ladies will be attached to these steamers. There will be a restaurant on these mail steamers.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: P. AND O. MAIL CONTRACTS.
div.p: In the yearly report of the P. and 0. Company, published recently, it is stated that the coming inauguration of a new mail service has rendered it necessary to resume building operations, and tenders were recently invited for the construction of mail and passenger steamers of the "M" class, but of larger tonnage, and fitted with such improvements as experience has shown to be desirable. Three vessels of this type have been contracted for, and appear in the fleet list under the names of "Malwa," "Mantua," and "Morea," the two first named being built by Messrs. Caird and Co., and the third ship by Messrs. Barclay, Curle, and Co.

A contract has also been made with Messrs. Caird and Co. for an express mail steamer of the Isis and Osiris type, but nearly four times as large, for the purpose of working the fort. nightly branch service between Aden and Bombay. This vessel will be named the Salsette.

The new mail contract was approved by the House of Commons towards the close of last session, almost exactly twelve months after the company's tender had been sent in. The con.. tract will run for seven years from Feb. 1st next, the annual subsidy being £305,000, or £53,000 less than the present annual subvention. At the same time, the services to be performed will be of a more arduous character, involving the following minimum speeds--namely:
The delivery of the mails will be effected as follows:--

div.head: "CAUSERIES D'EGYPTE."
div.p: In the volume under the above title, which has just been published M. Maspero reprints, with a few notes and emendations, the articles on Egyptian antiquities that he has contributed to the "Journal des Débáts." of the author it may be said without exaggeration that be touches nothing without making it interesting, and there is nothing in these essays which will not be read with the keenest pleasure by any one of an antiquarian turn of mind. Especially there may be recommended to the general reader's notice the article on the connexion of the Eleusinian Mysteries with Egypt; the many tales, fantastic and otherwise, here summarized ; and the study on those mummied animals which of all things in Egypt strike the modern tourist as the most removed from his ideas. If we look for essays which will appeal more to those who study Egyptology systematically, we shall find them in M. Maspero's remarks on the works at Deir el-Bahari, the Sun-temples at Abusir and elsewhere, and the controversy which has arisen over the supposed mummy of Queen Tii, which he regards as really that of Khuenaten's son-in law and successor, Se-aa-ka-ra "The Athenaeum" says, a pleasant feature in the book is the impartial manner in which M. Maspero praises the work of other Egyptologists, whether French, English, Swiss, or German, his avowed object being to discourage no one, and therefore not to speak of any man's labours unless he can say something in their favour. In this, as in other matters, he has shown himself an ideal Director of the Service des Antiquités.

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: MOBERLY. On the 8th inst, at the Anglo-Amotican Hospital, the wife of Maurice Moberly, of a son.

div.head: Nile Valley Co.
div.p: During November the battery crushed 1,160 tons for a yield of 293 ozs.

div.head: Bubonlc Plague.
div.p: One case of plague has been discharged cured at Deirout, there are now only eighteen cases under treatment.

div.p: The subscriptions received up to date for the celebration of the Khedive's Accession Anniversary in Cairo total L.E. 576.

div.head: Societa Filodrammatica Ernesto Rossl.
div.p: A performance of "II Viaggio dei Berluron" will be given by this society at the new hall in Rue Abou Dardar to-morrow evening, commencing at 9 o'clock.

div.head: Tour Eiffel.
div.p: Monsieur Provost has recovered from his indisposition and will give his representation to-night of the heads of 100 well-known people and will also play "Les Petites Brebis".

div.head: Duel Prevented by Police.
div.p: Kaimakam Aziz Bey el Torci and Mr. Alfred Tueni, who had a dispute in Cairo, were prevented yesterday morning by the police from fighting an arranged duel at Ramleh.

div.head: North Egypt Land Co.
div.p: It is stated that the North Egypt Land Company Limited (in liquidation) many possibly be reconstituted under . another name. Mr. Bromwich, Chairman of the Board of Directors, has arrived in Egypt from London.

div.head: Fire In Cairo.
div.p: A serious fire broke out last night at 10 o'clock in a shop occupied by a M. Eltriko, and though the fire brigade were promptly on the scene the fire was not extinguished for two hours. The estimated damage is put at LE 800, while the place was insured for only half that amount.

div.head: Egyptian Cotton In W. Africa.
div.p: The experiments with Egyptian cotton seed in the Gold Coast colony have not proved successful. The yield was only 248lbs. per acre, and the quality very inferior. This and subsequent experiments have established the conclusion that Egyptian cottons are not suitable to the climate of the colony.

div.head: New Kuttab Opened.
div.p: A new school was opened at Robomaieh on the ninth inst, founded by Mohamed Bey Abaza, who had invited many to attend the ceremony. Among those present were Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Grant, the Mudir of Sharkieh, and the Director of the Kattabs Department.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O. Alexandria,at 3.10 pm on Sunday 15th for ordinary correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered correspondence, at noon for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p.m. on Saturday 14th for parcels.

div.head: Fires at Alexandria.
div.p: There was an outbreak of fire in a cotton store at Souk el-Goma this morning. The cotton was damaged by water, but the building is intact. The Alexandria Fire Brigade was called out early yesterday afternoon to a small fire in Ras el-Tin street and another fire broke out at 3.40 p.m. in a general dealer's store in Cairo station street. The contents were damaged by water.

div.head: Cosmopolitan Egypt.
div.p: In his last report Lord Cromer expressed the wish to see Egypt keep its cosmopolitan characteristic. To be able to understand each other the different parts of the population must necessarily speak several languages. Only the Berlitz Schools can procure quickly that knowledge, thanks to their method universally renowned. Trial lesson free to all wishing to see for themselves its efficiency. [Advt.).

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GRAVING DOCK.
div.p: There is some probability that the graving dock at Gabbary will be lengthened in order to give admittance of the large vessels now coming regularly to Alexandria. For example the dock is fifteen feet too small to admit the S.S. "Heliopolis," which would under other circumstances dock here every two months and with the S.S. "Cairo" and the third steamer, which it is proposed to be built it would mean that the steamers of the Egyptian Mail Company would use the dock eighteeen times a year. Each steamer has a crew of 350 men, who would spend during their stay in dock about £500 in the town every time the vessel was docked. The SS. "Heliopolis" will now he obliged to use the graving dock at Toulon or Gecoa, and will expend considerable sums in docking the ship, annual overhauls, etc., in these ports instead of at Alexandria.

The Cunard S.S. Veria" sailed for Liverpool - yesterday afternoon, with 2,806 bales of cotton and will be followed by the S.S. "Pavia," due here on the 17th inst.

div.head:
SECRET HISTORY OF EGYPT.
BLUNTS' SECOND EDITION.
CONTRADICTIONS PUBLISHED.
div.p: Loddon, Friday. Mr. Frederic Harrison writes to the "Times" contradicting the statement made by Mr. W.S. Blunt in the second edition of the "Secret History of the Occupation of Egypt that he was the semi-official apologist of still living members of Gladstone's Government of 1882. The only works in his private letters published last July were an assertion that he did not believe that Mr. Gladstone, Lord Gran. ville, and Mr. Morley knowingly.conspired to have the Minister of a friendly state murdered in cold blood by Turkish officials and that these ministers intrigued to get murder done. In another letter he said "I do not believe that Morley wrote or even saw the passages you cite" from the "Pall Mall Gazette" re Arabi's murder. He had not discussed the Egyptian question with Mr. Morley since they differed about it in 1882.

div.head:
CAIRO OPERA SEASON.
SIGURD.
div.p: The most unsatisfactory aspect of "Sigurd" was, and is, the music. Long, arid stretches of three time sentiment or indolent recitation, scarcely relieved by flashes of pseudo-Wagnerişin, discourage singers and listeners alike.

The performance--if it is fair to criticise a performance in which the participants have so little scope was good. The chorus was excellent : time, accuracy and quality of voice were conspicuous, an amazing improvement on former years. Of the principals M. Valette was quite the best: his appearance was always a lucid interval amid the misty fainéantism of those four long, long acts. Mr. Soubeyrau was correct and at moments emphatic and excellent. Mlle Magne was also most adequate and consistent, as was the high priest. Mlle Robertson has a charming voice and presence, but again one cannot help remembering Mlle Devilloy in the part last year. We do not wish to make comparisons between this and last, or any other year, but Mlle Devilloy was one bright particular star, and cannot be forgotten, though this need be no disparagement of her talented successor. At moments the orchestra seemed to become bored and took refuge in profusion of sound, especially when the brass was concerned, but as a whole it was well directed and exact. Some of the audience seem to have established a pleasing and facile basis of applause, governed one may say by the three dimension theory - length, strength, and height. The moment M. Soubeyran rose above a certain note, the clapping commenced: if he retained the note, it increased, if he strengthened it, the manual labour became frantic. Perhaps this explains the popularity of wrestlers and strong men in general in this country. Be it noted, however, that a certain section of the abonnés discouraged this rather promiscuous test of ability and did not applaud until the dimensions of the singing approached the limit of the normal. As far as M. Valette was concerned they were justified : his volume and resonance exactly fitted, or rather enhanced, the some -what indigent music set before him. I retract exactly fitted; it is not fair on M. Valette : he onn do ample justice , to far better music. Incidentably we may all compliment Mr.Poucet on the entre-actes : they are now of reasonable length, and give just time for one cigarette and a few words of appreciation. It his company achieves as much for performance as he has for organisation, we may well pardon last year, and hope to enjoy, without prejudice or over-indulgence, our present season. We may even contemplate a momentary exculpation of the high local authorities who manage Mr. Poncet and Cairo opera in general.

div.head:
A NEW" EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
"LA RURALE D'EGYPTE.".
div.p: A syndicate of Belgian and Egyptian financiers has just formed a new land company, "La Rurale d'Egypte," which will acquire lands from the Société Anonyme da Béhéra, The capital is 10,000,000 fr , in. 40,000 shares of 250 fr. each There will also be 24.000 founders' shares, to be allotted as remuneration to the promoters, for option, expenses, etc.

The principal object of the company is to acquire and turn to account. uncultivated lands, to improve those already cultivated, and to resell the same. Profits will be divided as follows, after deducting the legal reserve:-- 5 per cent. interest to the shares. Of the gurplus, 15 per cent. will go to the board and balf of the balance to the ordinary shares and half to founders' shares.

The Egyptian group interested in this enterprise includes prominent financiers like Messrs. Salvago, Zervudachi, the director of the Crédit Lyonnais, etc. Amongst the Belgian promoters may be mentioned MM. Lepreux and M. Solvay, one of the most prominent men in Belgium.

In Egypt the management will be in the hands of an agricultural engineers, who has twenty-five years experience in the country, The Company has options on several agricultural properties The guaranteeing syndicats formed in Belgium, with offices at 43, Rae Royale, in this city, has received a large number of adhesions, and the bulk of the capital is already subscribed, the Egyptian group taking as its share two - and a-half million francs, or a quarter of the whole.

div.head: S.S. "HELIOPOLIS."
div.p: The official inauguration of the wonderful voyage of the S.S. "Heliopolis" in three days from Marseilles to Alexandria took place yesterday in the shape of a lunch given to five hundred notables, including Princes, Diplomatic Agents and Consuls General, Judges of the Mixed and Native Tribunals, officials of all the Government Departments and a select gathering of representatives of commercial, banking, and other interests in Alexandria and Cairo. A special train left Cairo at 8 15 a.m. with the numerous guests from the Capital and arrived at Gabbary Docks at 11.40. a m. The game train returned to Cairo at 5.p.m. from Alexandria, arriving at the Capital at 8.25 p.m. At one o'clock lunch was served The menu was as follows:--
Consommé en Tasse, Sole Frites, Viandes Froides Assorties, Salade de Légumes, Gelées Khedive, Glace au Fraises, Patisserie, Fruits.
The wines were as follows:--
Graves Superieur, St. Julien, 1900, St. Marceau, 1900, Vve Cliquot, 1898, Pommery Greno, 1900, Lanson Frerés, 1900, Denis Moumé, 1865, Liqueurs.

The Neapolitan Band played during the repast. After the banquet the guests were conducted over the abip and inspected with much interest the "Lusitania" of the Medi. terranean, as all travellers now call this magnificent vessel. Captain Graham Holloway, R.N.R., in command of the ship, and the officers entertained the guests by explaining the general technicalities of this floating palace, including the Marconigram apparatus, which enables the vessel to announce the news of the day at the breakfast table.

div.head: LORD CROMER FUND.
div.p: We refer our readers to the paragraph in to-days' issue, notifying the meeting to be held at the British Club on Monday the 16th at 4 p.m. The circular of the committee issued to members of British nationality says :--
Alexandria, E., 11 Dec. 1907.
Dear Sir,
"Concerning the Proposal of a Testimonial to LORD CROMER"

It is felt that it would be agreeable to members of the British Community to subscribe to a farewell Testimonial to Lord Cromer who, during his nearly 24 years of residence in Egypt as H.B.M. Agent and Consul General, did so much both directly and indirectly for the welfare of this country and for British interest in general.
It is proposed that the Testimonial should take the form of an annual Prize or of a Scholarship at the Victoria College to be competed for by the boys, irrespective of nationality.
I should be much obliged if you could tell me whether you agree to this proposal and in that case, what you are willing to subscribe.
I am, Dear Sir,
Your faithfully,
ROBERT J. Moss,
Chairman of Committee.

We are requested to state if any British resident in Alexandria has not received his copy that a copy would be at once furnished him on application to the Chairman, Mr. Robert J. Moss, at the offices of Messrs. R. J. Moss and Co. Alexandria.

The Committee, as is no doubt known, is formed of Messrs. H. P. Kingham, Victor F. Naggiar, Judge Sandars, Wm. T. Smith, and will individually receive subscriptions, or these can be paid direct to the Anglo-Egyptian Bank.

div.head:
PORTS AND LIGHTS.
TRIAL OF OFFICIALS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - If the account in yesterday's 'Egyptian Gazette" is a true version of the procedure of a Native Court we must condemn it as a mere parody of justice, The, speech of the Chief of the Parquet, it a correct translation from the Arabic, appears on the face of things a mere tissue of misstatements from beginning to end, and facts known to the authorities have been twisted to serve some sinister purpose of the Egyptian party in politics. The verdicts have been based merely on circumstantial evidence, a method which is not accepted by the police authorities. The report, I hope is faulty, the result 1, of an imperfect knowledge of the Arabie, language, and I should be glad to procure a translation of the 'conte rendu' by some good Arabic scholar giving the cross-examination of witnesses. The report as it stands is an instructive revelation as to the fitness of the Egyptiang to judge his own compatriote. But this, I believe, is the 'nen policy, and may serve.as a good object lesson to the natives of this country of the capacity of their own lawyers and judges. To give only one or two examples. The Chief of the Parquet showed how Safwat tried by all means to get a bribe of L.E. 40 from one Ismail Hassan of Rosetta and also L.E. 5 from Mahmoud Neguib - bribes for placing people in Government posts—and we find him acquitted ! Again, the Chief of the Parquetgives an absolutely incorrect account of the first finding out of bribery and corruption in the Ports and Lights Administration, trying to give all the credit to the Finance Ministry, instigated no doubt, by some sinister means, to support the "Enquiries" and Conseil de Discipline which were dominated by a native official who was favoured by the Minister of Finance. There must be some truth in the remark which is being banded about on all sides "that the British authorities are giving the natives the proverbial long rope to hang themselves".
Truly Yours

div.head: HELOUAN.
div.p: Following on the opening of the casino and gardens on Saturday last, the new Club, known as the "Helouan International Club," has been opened under, most promising auspices, and Attracted a very large crowd of residents, and visitors from Cairo, who enjoyed one of Egypt's sunniest and balmiest of days in the very pleasantest of spots, rendered gay by the strains of the excellent band of the King's Royal Rifles. The magnificent marquee attracted many tea parties, and the scene was as brilliant as any yet chronicled from Helouan. The gardens this year have been laid out with so much taste, that the former stigma of aridness attached to the name of Helouan is at once completely refuted and forgotten, and the several attractions offered to the public for the small charge of P.T. 2, ensures the success of the very excellent scheme and arrangement due to the initiative of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways.

The Helouan International Club has been formed with the substantial assistance of the Delta Railway Management, who have made. over to the committee, composed of several of the leading residents of Helouan as representing the different communities, several of the upper rooms of the casino building where everything up to date in the matter of equipment is to be found, and from the many applications for membership there can be little doubt but that the move is immediately and thoroughly appreciated by the largest and most influential of the resident population.

The club is purely a social one, and offers A rendezvous that Helouan has greatly wished for, and from the remarks made in an address at the opening ceremony by, a prominent Egyptian resident, the aim of the club would be to cement the friendship of all races living in Egypt, to promote, concord, and disperse all misunderstandings. These sentiments were cordially endorsed by all present, and the first meeting of the committee and members ended in a prevailing feeling that a firmer friendship was about to be established.

The club is to be run during the winter season, and to afford all the comforts and attractions that modern day institutions of that kind are able to offer, such as writing, reading, card, and billiard rooms, etc, and three billiard tables to a club newly formed is indicative of what one may expect for the rest in the matter of provision for the needs of its members. We wish the Helonan International Club a hearty send off and a successful career, and were it possible to make Helonan slightly more accessible than it is at present, such as a direct communication, by road with Cairo, we have no doubt but that many Cairenes would be found enrolled amongst its members.

div.head:
EDUCATION OF MOHAMEDANS.
GATHERING AT PORT SAID.
div.p: A large gathering, of high functionaries and notables of Port Said was held at the Eastern Exchange Hotel last week to wish success to Osman Eff. Raafat, who is returning to Bingapore, and takes with him four fellow countrymen to carry on the working of a Mohammedan school he has established there. The assembly was held under the presidency of Hassan Eff. Bakhry, Mamour of Cherif Basin Customs, who had organized a very able committee to arrange the proceed. ings, with a reception and tea, followed by a dinner at 9 o'clock at which the Governor of the Suez Canal, Moheb Pasha, the SubGovernor, Riad Bey, and the Judge of the Native Court, Izzet Bey, were among those present.

The Sheikh el Ulema was called upon to open the after dinner oratory. Moheb Pasha in his speech alluded to the happy idea of the President in celebrating this unique occasion in such a befitting manner, and urged the mission to be diligent and courageous.

Other speeches followed in which were set forth the excellent, and for this country the almost unprecedented, example set by Osman Eff. Raafat in leaving Egypt to take up his. home in a far country like Singapore, and to establish a school there for the benefit of his 00-religionists, also referring to the fact that he had returned only to secure further help by selecting Egyptian teachers. A hope was also expressed that he would again return to secure higher grade teachers as the needs of the work demanded.

It was also pointed out that the Egyptians are about the only nation who have no love for emigration which has hitherto been a bár to their progress, and on this account the efforts of this gallant band of teachers deserve the highest commendation.

div.head:
OBITUARY.
SIR G. MACPHERSON GRANT.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of the father of the Alexandrian Agent of the Sudan Government which took place suddenly in Edinburgh last week. Bir George MaophersonGrant, was. from 1879 to 1886. member of Parliament for the Counties of Elgin and Nairn.. He took a prominent part in county Affairs, and was a well-known breeder of Angus cattle. Sir George was born in 1839, and succeeded to to the baronetey on the death of his father in 1850. His son John, who was born in 1868, succeeds to the title and estates.

The death of Sir George Macpherson Grant will place a number of people in mourning in Scotland, where he was quite a great personage. He was always one of the most energetic members of the committee of the Northern Meeting at Inverness in his younger days, and his son, the new Baronet, is equally well-known and popular there. The new Lady Macpherson Grant was Miss Mary Dennistoun, daughter of the late Mr Alexander Dennistoun, of Gold: hill, and Mrs. Dennistoun, who lives very quietly at her own place, Row, in Dumbartonshire.

div.head: NILE RESERVOIRS AND COTTON CROP.
div.p: Sir William Willcocks is going to give a lecture on the 21st inst. at a meeting of the Khedivial Geographical Society in Cairo on "Nile Reservoirs and the Cotton Crop". This lecture will embody all he learned, on his journey to the equator and gives an account of the cotton he saw from Alexandria to the equator and a description of the White Nile as Sir William saw it. He will then show how valuable three sites are for reservoirs, and estimates how readily Egypt and the Sudan, could be irrigated all over for £1,500,000. He will give a criticism of the Assouan dam as being raised and of the Cairo water supply as bearing on the question of green water and reservoirs.

div.head: GOLD RETURN
div.p: During the first week of this month the import of gold was L.E. 60,219 and export L.E. 31,472, exclusive of Post Office specie.

div.head: MILITARY NOTES.
div.p: Capt. Evan H. Llewellyn, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted the temporary rank of Lieutenant Colonel, whilst employed as Commandant of a Battalion of the King's African Rifles.
Capt. Robert P. Dalrymple, K.R.R., has been seconded for services with the Egyptian Army.
Q. M. and Hon. Lt. W. Johnson, Coldstream Guards, has been granted the honorary rank of Captain.
Lt. G. H. Barnett, K.R.R, attains the rank of Captain vice R. F. Sims, D.S.0., resigned.
Lt. C. P. Heywood, Coldstream Guards, has been seconded for service with the Egyptian Army.
Second Lt. J. S. Mellor, K.R.R, attains the rank of Lieutenant vice A.J. Fife, seconded.

The Rev. E.M. Morgan, Chaplain to the Foroes, has arrived in Egypt. and has been taken on the strength of the Army of Occupation and has assumed the duties of Senior Chaplain to the Forces (R.C.) in Egypt.
The Rev. C. Clouston, Porri, having arrived in Egypt, has been taken on the strength of the Command and has assumed the duties of Senior Wesleyan Chaplain in Egypt.

Sir Hugh Smiley, is, we are glad to learn making an excellent recovery from his recent severe indisposition. He will visit Egypt with Lady Smiley later in the season.
Mr. Iddings, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, paid a visit yesterday to his Royal Highness Prince George at Shepheard's Hotel.
Mr. and Mrs. G. E. Duveen, who arrived bry. the "Heliopolis" and who are on their honey. moon are staying at the Savoy, Cairo.
Other passengers by the same boat included Capt. C. Magne, Mr. J. Lang Mr. Hope, Mr. F. Cohen, Mr. P. H. Bromwick, and Mr. N. Alchersky.
Amongst the many literary people at present staying at Shepheard's are Mr. and Mrs. Clement Shorter, Mr. Sydney Low, and Mr. and Mme Huret.
Mr. R. Hitchens has arrived in Cairo from Luxor. He hopes later on to return to Upper Egypt and to pay a visit to Abu Simbet.

In yesterday's issue we announced that Mr. Montagu Summers had arrived in Egypt by the S.S. "Isis." A London contemporary says that Mr. Summers "Will devote his time to his many other interests in Egypt."

Professor Goodman, who is professor of Civil and Mechanical Engineering at the Leeds University, has arrived in Egypt and is staying at Shepheard's Hotel, where he will remain during his stay in Cairo, but it is his intention to visit the Sudan before leaving the country.
Judge Fleming, of the Sudan Legal Administration, who is taking the quarterly circuit of the Sudan has arrived in the Halla District.
Mr. J. Gooding barrister at law, to state that his office in now situated within the offices of Mr. Georges Prangondis, Avocat, Rue St. Marks, over Restaurant l'Egypt.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN TRADE CRISIS.
AFFAIRS OF MR. NICOLAS DOKI.
div.p: In the Manchester County Court on Wednesday week application was made to his Honour Judge Parry to approve of a scheme of composition proposed by Mr. Nicolas Doki, of this city and Beyrout, against whom a receiving order was made on October 4. Mr. Edgar, solicitor, appeared in support of the application.

The Official Receiver (Mr. J. Grant Gibson) presented a long report. It showed that the composition was approved by the required majority of creditors on November 21. Under it the debtor proposed to pay his debts in full, with interest at the rate of 5 per cent per annum, in the following manner:- 2s. 6d. in the pound at the end of one month from the date of the Court's approval, 58. in the pound six months afterwards, 5s in the pound twelve months afterwards, and 78. 6d. in the pound eighteen months afterwards. Mr. John Philip Garnett, chartered accountant, of Boothstreet, Manchester, was to be trustee. Of the fourteen creditor's for £11,461 admitted to vote, twelve creditors for £10,445 accepted the scheme.

The debtor's statement of affairs showed unsecured liabilities of £101, and liabilities on accommodation bills as acceptor or endorser £25,478, of which it was 'expected £17,750 would rank for dividend ; while the assets were estimated to produce £28,271. The debtor was engaged from 1888 to 1905 with various shipping firms doing business with Beyrout and the East and with South Africa and South America. They were successful, and in January, 1905, he found himself possessed of £8,000 capital, consisting mainly of book-debts assigned to him as his share of the assets of his old firm of Doki, Chiha, and Co., which was then dissolved. With this and £2,000 advanced by Messrs. R. Pharaon et Fils, of Beyrout, he began business on January 1, 1905, as a shipper and general merchant, under the style of N. Doki and Co., in Oxford-street, Manchester, and at Beyrout. The present position of the firm of N. Doki and Co. was that, apart from a certain liability on bills, it possessed assets of a value exceeding its liabilities by rather more than £10,000the estimated surplus assets of the Beyrout house over its liabilities, which were of small amount. The debtor bad from time to time discounted other than' purely trade bills, but no liability was likely to arise from this except in connection with his acceptances for Messrs. Pharaon, Cousins, and Co., of Cairo, for whose accommodation he had accepted bills amounting to £17,250. Messrs. Pharaon had filed in the Egyptian courts, the equivalent of a bankruptcy petition, and had submitted a scheme, which had been approved, for the pay. ment of twenty shillings the pound.

An essential feature of the scheme, the Official Receiver went on to say, was that all but 68. in the composition would be paid by Messrs. Pharaon, and that they would eventually refund to the debtor the 68. also. It was obvious that the complete fulfilment of the scheme depended on the solvency of Messrs. Pharaon, Cousins, and Co. The books of that firm had been examined by accountants, and showed assets to a snbstantial amount. At the same time the Official Receiver felt that the Court would be reluctant to sanction a proposal obviously of a precarious nature, and unlikely to result in real benefit to the creditors. The total provable liabilities at the date of the report were £16,785, whilst the debtor's own assets were likely to produce £10,000. The only matter in the debtor's own trading and conduct which "prima facie" might appear open to criticism was accepting bills to such a large extent for Messrs. Pharaon's accommodation ; but as the debtor had with perfect safety and benefit done financial business with them for twenty years, he could not be charged with rash and hazardous speculation. The Official Receiver understood that Messrs. Pharaon were at present perfectly solvent, but were temporarily in financial difficulty owing to the locking up of a lot of their capital in land, which, if thrown indiscriminately on the market, would produce disastrous effects not only to themselves but to other Egyptian firms.

Mr. Edgar, in submitting that the proposal was a reasonable one, pointed out that the whole of the assets were in Beyrout. He him. seif and Mr. Garnett, acting for the whole body of bankers concerned in the Egyptian failures, had had an investigation made, and he could assure the Court that the Official Receiver's report on the position of Messrs. Pharaon was very conservative. Moreover, he was now in a position to add that further assurance was to be found in the fact that the whole of the landed property of Messrs. Pharaon was included in a mortgage in the hands of the debtor's representatives in Cairo.
Judge Parry: That, of course, makes this scheme very much better.

Mr. Edgar said it was a matter which had come to hand since the Official Receiver drew, up his report. It would be within the recollection of the Court that a large number of Egyptian houses went down at the end of July, at the same time as Mr. Doki, in consequence of exceptional pressure there, and he was glad to say that not a single one of them up to the present had made any suggestion to its creditors of less than twenty shillings in the pound. To that the creditors were bound, he thought, not only in this instance but in all others of these failures to get twenty shillings in the pound.
His Honour Is the creditor here who did not assent?

Mr. Edgar: He is not. It is a foreign bank. The only objections we have had to these schemes, except where they have been carried privately, have come from Kankers abroad who have thought they could manage to get pay-ment in advance.

His Honour said he need not hear anything else. He was glad to find the scheme was even better than set out by the Official Receiver, and he hoped it would be carried out. In any case he did not intend to stand between creditors and twenty shillings in the pound. He found the schému reasonable and calculated to benefit the creditors, and he accordingly approved of it.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi) Il n'y a rien de changé -la situation d'hier, sinon que les meilleures dispositions manifestées un instant pour deux ou trois petites valeurs ont disparu. Seole l'United paralt bien tenue à 7/82-1/4. Les échanges font complètement défaut, les contre-parties étant impassibles à découvrir. Ceux même que se déclarent acheteurs se båtent de se retirer dès qu'ils ren contrent un vendeur authentique.
En National Bank, on a observé dès l'ouverture un recul sensible à 20 1/16 mais peu après la demande a poussé le cours à 20 1/4, soit 1/16 au-dessus de la clôture d'hier.

L'Agricole a été offerte à 7 7/8. Des offres ont ramené la Ramleh de 4 1/2 à 4 3/8, les Privilégiées Tramways de 140 à 139, les parts des Jouissances Eaux du Caire de 177 à 175, la Daïra Sapieh de 12 7/8 à 12 3/4,et la Banque d'Orient de 113 à 112 3/4.
L'Obligation Crédit Foncier elle-même rétrograde,en dépit da prochain tirage, de 287 1/2 à 287 l'ancienne et de 252 1/2 à 252 la nouvelle. Les Lots Turcs progressent, au contraire, de 160 à 161.
A 15 1/8 hier, les Nungovich Hotels, s'inscrivent aujourd'hui à 15 1/4 avec la délicieuse mention "nominal". La cote est pleine de ces anomalies.
Demandée hier à 45, la Cassa di Sconto est offerte à 44 3/4.

En baisse également l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 21/7 1/2 à 21/-, l'Investment de 3/8 å 11/32, le Comptoir de 2 15/32 2 7,16, l'A. boukir de 29/- à 28/9, l'action Allotment de 2 1/8 à 2 1/16, les Cotton Ginners de 1 1/4 d 1 7/32 et l'Helouan de 3/16 à 1/8.

Noug avons réservé pour la fin l'Urbaine qui avait été insorite hier à 3 5/16, hausse dont nous n'avions pu obtenir l'explication. La voici : elle témoignera da sérieux de certaines de nos agences. Alors que cette valeur était couramment offerte à 3 1/8, un courtier aurait soi-disant vendu en clôture 25 titres à 3 5/16 et aurait exigé la cotation à ce prix, malgré les protestations unanimes des vendears à 3 1/8. Aujourd'hui, naturellement, l'équilibre s'est rétabli de lui-même et le courtier en question n'ayant pas jugé à propos ! d'en vendre encore 25 à 3 5/16, le prix réel de 3 1/8 a été rétabli.

Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de variations appréciables à signaler. En somme, la semaine clôture comme elle avait commencé, c'est-à-dire dans l'inaction la plus complète. S'il y a une tendance, elle est pour la lourdeur, les vendeurs étant les plus nombreux.

div.head: Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company, Ltd.
ASSEMBLEE GENERALE ORDINAIRE.
AVIS
div.p: Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire le Lundi 30 Décembre 1907 à 4 heures de relevée aux Bureaux de la Compagnie à Alexandrie.
L'Ordre du Jour de cette Assemblée comprend :

1'.- Lecture du rapport du Conseil d'Administration et de celui du Censeur relatif aux Comptes de l'exercice du ler Octobre 1906 au 30 Septembre 1907 ; approbation des dits comptes et fixation du dividende.
2o-Nomination du Censeur pour l'exercice 1907-1908 et fixation de sa rétribution.
3o.- Nomination de deux membres sortants du Conseil d'Administration, conformément aux art. 37 et 38 des statuts, qui sont rééligibles.

Les Actionnaires porteurs d'au moins 20 actions qui voudraient assister à l'Assemblée ou s'y faire représenter, doivent déposer leurs actions & Alexandrie, au siège de la Compagnie, à la National Bank of Egypt, à la Banque Impériale Ottomane, à la Bank of Egypt Ltd, à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd, à la Banque de Salonique, à la Banco di Roma, à la Deutsche Orientbank Aktiengesellschaft et au Crédit Lyonnais, ou à Londres et à Paris à la Banque Impériale Ottomane ou à Bruxelles au Siège des Tramways d'Alexandrie, trois jours an moins avant celui fixé pour l'assemblée et le reçu qu'ils recevront en échange leur donnera le droit d'assister à l'assemblée soit personnellement soit par procuration.
Par ordre:
Le Directeur Général,
(Signé) J. G. Jacor,
Alexandrie le 13 Décembre 1907.

div.head: CEREAL MARKET
div.p: ROD EL FARAG

In a speech the congressman Mr. Fowler, chairman of the House Committee on banking and currency, insisted that gold was the only proper bank reserve. Notes and silver were stumbling block. America, he said, was becoming the financial centre of the world If the Government continued its present currency manipulations à commercial tragedy would arise compared with which the present was only a pleasant summer outing. (Reuter)
The manager of the branch of the California Safe Deposit and Trust Co. of San Francisc has committed suicide here. (Reuter)

President Roosevelt has issued a formal statement of renunciation of a third term of presidency. It is generally agreed here that this brings Governor Hughes to the fore. The democratic leaders declare that it improves the chances of their candidate. (Reuter)
A Macedonian last night fired at and killed the notorious revolutionary leaders Borissarafoff and Garvanoff.

After a successful short search by the police Panitza, nephew of the notorious Major Panitza whom they are suspicious of having being the murderer of Sarafoff, has been arrested. It is expected that the Government will arrest the chiefs of all the Macedonian committees. (Reuter)
Two explosions have wrecked Kynoch's powder mill near Barnsley. Two persons have been killed and several injured. (Reuter)
Prince George of Greece and Princess Marie Bonaparte have been married. The ceremony was brilliant. The streets were ablaze with decorations. (Reuter)
The marriage of Prince George has been celebrated and evoked the acclamations of enthusiastic crowds. (Havas)
The Reichstag is considering the proposal for the modification of the 1896 Bourse Law. (Havas)
The Chamber has adopted the compromise with Austria. (Havas)
Two bodies of reservists have been demobilised owing to the improved outlook. (Reuter)
The Kaiser has arrived aboard the yacht "Hohenzollern." (Havas)
M. Brenner, Radical, has been elected President of the Confederation. (Havas)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Major Vivian Henry, who recently retired from the Royal Fusiliers, and who was com. mandant of the Mounted Infantry in Egypt, has been selected for the command of the 8th Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, or Carlow Militia. It is a smart little eorps of four companies.

Lieutenant G. H. Barnett, 4th. Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, has been promoted captain, Captain Barnett served a little over eight years for his company, and was employed with the Mounted Infantry in the Transvaal and Orange River operations, in the course of which he has severely wounded (Queen's medal with five clasps).

Lieutenant Heywood, Coldstream Guards ; Lieutenant Davenport, Lancashire Fusiliers; Lieutenant Wheatley, Dorsetshire. Regiment, and Captains Daubney and Ryan, Essex Regiment, have been seconded in their respective regiments for service with the Khedive's army.

Cavalrymen in Egypt will be interested to know that the new sword-designed specially for thrusting—is now being used in the regiments of the First Cavalry Brigade, Aldershot, for the purpose of being reported upon. Like many another thing, it is the outcome of experience in the South African War, in the course of which the regulation sword was found next to useless, being designed rather for slashing than pointing. The natural inclination of the muscular Anglo Saxon is to hew down his enemy by the downright dint of physical force, whereas the Latin races are inclined to give the more deadly point. The new weapon is a little bit longer, and lighter than the regulation sword. It is edgeless till the last seven inches of the point, where it is sharpened keenly into a tapered point of deadly thrusting powers. The blade is of the best steel, and to give it rigidity the back is thickened. The hilt balances the weapon nicely and gives complete protection to the hand.

Those who know the history of South Africa advise caution with regard to the alarming rumours from that quarter. They do not deny the possibility of a rising among the Zulu tribes, but they call to mind the fact that there are plenty of not too scrupulous people in the Southern portion of the African Continent whose interest it is to exaggerate any bad news that might be forthcoming. It used to be said that Cape Colony never flourished save when there was a war on hand, and Great Britain was pouring men and stores into the -country, and Cape Colony is not particularly flourishing just now.

With a view to the absorption of supernumerary non-commissioned officers of reduced regiments created by the disbandment of their - 3rd and 4th Batalions, the Army Council has under consideration a suggestion that these non-commissioned officers shall be transferred, if they consent, to other regiments, carrying with them the date of seniority in their rank Before coming to a decision in the matter, the Army Council has called for information as to what number of supernumerary non commissioned officers of the regiments in question are desirious of being so transferred.
The 1st Battalion Yorkshire Regiment, on arrival next month, will be stationed in Alexandria it is understood.

The militia of the United Kingdom will train under the old conditions in the coming year. In fact, it is believed that the whole scheme of militia reform is about to be shelved indefinitely, for want of funds.

The first of the battleships to return home from the Mediterranean under the new conditions is the "Formidable," Captain Herbert Lyon, and which will be replaced by the battleship "Goliath," Captain F.S. Miller.

The battle squadron of the Atlantic Fleet is reported to have done well at the recent practice off Gibraltar, the scores being-"Al bemarie," 36 bits; "Cornwallis" 33 hits ; "Exinouth," 32 hits ; "Albion," 31, all with the 12 and 6 inch guns.
The troopship "Rewa" will leave Southampton on the 18th with close on 1200 troops on board for Karachi. She will reach Port Said about the 28th inst.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, to a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within cortannonsery limits--free discussion.

div.head: COMPANIES IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir, - It has often been remarked by the careful observer that when there is any disturbance in a seething mass of anything, strange matters come to the surface. Although Egypt is not such an interesting place to live in as it was thirty years ago, it is still a land of broad contrasts, and these are often more apparent to the stranger than to those to whom habit has made things familiar. A few days since I happened to go from here to Cairo in the same carriage with an intelligent lady who had just landed in Egypt for the first time. Referring to the noisy landing she said : "The natives seem very violent, are they dangerous?" I was pleased to reassure her on this point. This lady was surprised at the European appearance of Alexandria, but much more so when we passed the first Arab village and pointing to the mud huts, asked what those things were ? I replied that those were the houses the people lived in who made the wealth of this country, of which we European residents helped them to spend a part. The lady said she had no idea that in this 20th century, there was any part of the world in which human beings lived in such a way.

As our train took just three hours longer, than it should have done, to reach Cairo, this lady had ample time for observation, and I fancy that but for the language we were speaking, and the courtesy due to a stranger, from whom some further information might possibly be acquired, she would have liked to say something far from complimentary, as to the effect on the natives of the influence of both foreign residents and a foreign occupation.

Later on when I saw this lady in the luxurious halls of Shepheard's hotel, and expressed the hope that the unpleasant impressions of the morning had been removed, she said, - "this is indeed a country of strange contrasts," but I do not think that she had forgotten, the mud huts, or the lack of clothes exhibited by some of their inhabitants.

Although Egypt is only a very small part of the world, it has for some years past, attracted a very large amount of attention; its great antiquity, its assimilation of the most modern appliances, its sudden evolution from bankruptcy to a flourishing financial position, the change in the status of its people from something closely approaching slavery to an almost exuberant liberty, the remarkable development of its commerce, the host of new companies, the wild speculation, the inevitable crisis, all these things have attracted the attention of the civilised world in a degree altogether out of proportion to the size of the country.

For some years past up to the spring of this year, everything seemed to go on wheels; —then came the crisis, and it began to be found out that many of the new companies started, had no cause for existence, and that their shares though rup up by wild speculation to several times their par value, were only a drug on the market. Very many of these companies were formed under the English law of limited liability. This law is based on many Acts of Parliament from 1862 to 1907, all of them more or less obscure, and this same obscurity has for many years been largely taken advantage of, to do many things which ought not to have been done, and to neglect obligations which should have been complied with.

But if the former Acts of Parliament left a pleasing doubt on the mind as to liability for neglect of duty, and such doubts have been, once and for ever, very clearly removed by a new Act dated August in this year of Grace 1907. There is no doubt about this Act ;-it puts on companies and more particularly on their directors penalties hitherto unheard of; enough to make one's hair stand on end, so steep is the way, and 80 Darrow is the only path, by which they may be avoided. The number of people in Egypt who are directors of limited liability companies, must be legion, but to any honest man who has not already got his head in the noose, and who may have some foolish wish to see his name figure on a list of Directors, my advice is that which was given by "Punch" to the man hesitating about getting married ;-—-"don't".

As soon as I heard of the new Act I sent for a copy, but when it came it was useless It refers to every imaginable act passed before. I was in an out of the way place, where the old Acts were not to be found, and it was only when I got home, surrounded by a pretty ample legal library that I was able to find out where my responsibilities ended.

I am glad to see in your paper of yesterday that your correspondent "Lex" has taken up the question, but in the first place I do not quite agree with what he seems to infer, and secondly I think his proposal though right in principle is too drastic in form. He seems to infer that men of other than British nationality can infringe the law with impunity. I would recommend these gentlemen to lay no such flattering unction to their souls ; the British law has a long arm, and if necessary it has an uncomfortable way of getting outside assistance, and in my opinion it would be better for all directors of British limited liability companies of whatever nationality they may be to put their house in order without much loss of time.

I cannot believe that our Parliament would intentionally have passed an act from which it might result that a British subject sitting on the Board of an English Company, should find himself at a disadvantage with his foreign colleagues. If such should prove to be the case the sooner it is remedied the better, and I appeal to you Sir, through the medium of your columns, to submit this important matter

div.head: K. S. C.
JUNIOR POLO TOURNAMENT
div.p: FINALS.

Before a very large gathering of spectators the final of the tournament was played off on Wednesday between the King's Own Scottish Borderers and the 60th Rifles. The excellent form shewn by the 60th was a surprise to most. That they were a vastly improved team we all knew, but the jump they have made in the last week is a big one. Their hitting was very good, and they were quicker on to the ball than their opponents. Each member of the team did his share of the work and it is hard to pick out any one as having excelled over the others. Mr. Evans is a lusty No I., and rides his mare well. Mr. Seymour and Capt. H. B. Kennedy hit straight and well, and Mr. Hope at back was seldom caught napping. At the same time we have never seen the K.O.S.B. so off their game ; their hitting was weak and their ponies seemed slow at starting. Capt. Kennedy, who can be so brilliant at times, was especially disappointing.

From the throw in the 60th gave an example of what was to follow. They got away with the ball and scored in the first half minute ; and shortly afterwards added 2 more goals to which the K.O.S B. retaliated with a solitary goal. The 60th then seemed to be always attacking and the score mounted up. The K.O.S.B. were very unfortunate in their shots at goal, several attempts only just missing. The last chukker Capt. Stoney scored again for the K.O. S.B. with a very neat back hander. Final scores 60th Rifles 8 goals ; K.O.S.B. 2 goals. The 60th have our hearty congratulations on their victory.

div.head: HELOUAN RACES.
div.p: The following is the racing programme of the Helouan December Skye Meeting, to be held at Helouan on Friday, 20th December, at 2 pm. under the Rules and kind co-operation of the Stewards of the Khedivial Sporting Club.

THE CHAMPION STAKES. Value P.T. 1600, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 800, 2rd horse to Teceive P.T. 200 out of the stakes. Forced and limited entry for all horses, Galloways and Ponies entered in any race of this Meeting. Weight for age and inches. Distance mile. Entrance P.T. 50
The entries will close at 6 pm on Saturday the 14th December 1907, to the Clerk of the Course, Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan

The order of running will be the same as that in which the races are on this programme.
